message: /* On “Conflict of Interest” in Wikipedia editing */ Reply
Unsourced and non factual statements. No consensus was reached. Everything was already largely explained in the talk section as well as the fact that there's not any conflict of interests.
/* combined rankings */ Reply
/* combined rankings */ Reply

You can't decide on your own. How do you justify that there's nothing about that on the internet? How do you justify standards being different and still trying to compare overall score? Deciding on your own to pick single scores when iam ranking works with average? Who are you to decide what to pick and what not? Wikipedia is an encyclopedia, not a personal blog.

You have to cite sources. How do you justify that there's nothing about that on the internet? How do you justify standards being different and still trying to compare overall score? Deciding on your own to pick single scores when iam ranking works with average? Who are you to decide what to pick and what not? Wikipedia is an encyclopedia, not a personal blog.
To be 'clear' and 'objective' it needs to have an external source. Why there are not? Because it's not true, scoring and rankings work differently.
The scores show Muzii as the IAM wmc and he is. You can't insert personal statements on wikipedia, especially if they are unsourced and wrong, like explained in the talk section.
/* combined rankings */ Reply

Subjective comparison between associations are made here. Standards and type of rankings are different between the 2 so they can't be objectively compared. In fact there are no external sources cited of this comparison and rankings.
/* combined rankings */ Reply

Athletes of different associations are not competing against each other by definition. The individual trying to add this information should learn why this was not mentioned for years in the page and what are the wmsc procedures that originated iam creation.

Pure vandalism is being made here. Reasons largely explained in the talk section. Zero external references of these statement, uncited and inconsitent.
Cited sources do not provide these informations. Rankings and scoring work differently between associations.

The point is that you can't write your ideas on wikipedia. A source that clearly says these informations (8th, 4th...) need to externally exists. And it doesn't exist because the 2 associations works differently.

As discussed in the talk section, the source cited doesn't make any reference to these statements. Plus, the 2 associations work with different types of scoring and rankings so you can't simply compare them.
Reason of the edit explained in the talk section, as previously mentioned.

The points serve to give readers a better perspective of the World Best score in 2019 and current highest-rated player of all-time (having taken into account the fact that they did not compete against each other). It is immaterial that “this was not mentioned for years”. Points can be added at any point in time. He wasn't the only to win in first year: Ryu, who won the WMSC event in the same yeart and had a higher total score, also did it in her first year (first event, in fact). Also added some scores from WMSC due to the fact that some his 'records' aren't 'true' records in combined stats scenario.
new tournament

Same reasons as before. For single disciplines this can instead be done and should remain in the page. Regarding the all time best score this should be removed because with the new IAM standards Alex Mullen is now first again and Andrea Muzii is second.
new results added

Added score from WMSC for perspective (there are now two organizations hosting World Memory Championships - WMSC & IAM). Two of his records aren’t ‘true’ records in combined statistics scenario. Citation of list of records from the WMSC site is provided for reference.
